data.title: Odesa
data.text:
Archaeological findings confirm that the area of today's Odesa has been inhabited since antiquity, and the inhabitants of this territory were strongly associated with the Mediterranean. In the Middle Ages, this area changed hands, being under the rule of the Pechenegs, Polovtsians, the Golden Horde, the Crimean Khanate, the Grand Duchy of Lithuania and the Golden Horde. The first written mention of a settlement on the territory of today's Odesa dates back to 1415 and refers to the Tatar port settlement called Kaczubeiow, which was later renamed to Hajiba.

After the Treaty of Jassy (1791), ending the Sixth Russian-Turkish War, Odesa came under Russian rule. In 1795, according to the decree of Empress Catherine II, the port of Hajiba was founded, the Odessa war and trade port. During the construction of the city, emigrants from the revolutionary France (today the patrons of the main downtown streets) played a key role, primarily Prince Armand-Emanuel Richelieu de La Porte, General Louis Alexandre Andranault Langeron and Joseph Deribas.

The 19th century was a period of intensive development for Odessa as a result of grain export. The city received city rights in 1803, then the number of inhabitants increased from 9,000. up to 500 thousand in 1904, settlers who came from all over the Russian Empire, the Balkans and Greece to the city created an incredible cultural melting pot here. In 1865, the railway reached Odessa - first the line was led to Balta, and in 1870 - to Kiev. Before the revolution, about 500 companies operated here. The Bolshevik rise to power caused a crisis and mass emigration of the city's inhabitants.

From August to October 1941 there was a fierce defense of the Odessa naval base against German and Romanian forces advancing from the land. In the years of the World War II, until the liberation of the city by the Red Army in April 1944, Odessa was occupied by Romanians. After rebuilding the war damage, the city began to develop rapidly. The second half of the 20th century brought significant changes in the ethnic structure of the city's population: Jews emigrated from Odessa. Many of them later settled in New York near Brighton Beach, creating there the so-called "Little Odessa".

Contemporary Odessa is very popular among tourists. Guests from all over the world are attracted by: warm climate, beautiful sandy beaches and a unique multicultural atmosphere. Thanks to the film "Battleship Potemkin", the city is associated with the Potemkin Stairs (this is a vast staircase that creates the illusion, so that only a few large stairs are visible at the top, and at the bottom all the stairs seem to combine into one pyramidal mass), connecting the port with the city.

In 1810 the first opera house was opened (destroyed by fire in 1873). The modern building was built by Fellner and Helmer in a neo-baroque style. The luxurious hall was built in the Rococo style. It is said that thanks to the unique acoustics, even a whisper from the stage can be heard in every part of the room. Many buildings in Odessa have the style of nineteenth-century classical architecture. This is particularly evident in buildings designed by architects such as Italy Francesco Boffo, who at the beginning of the 19th century built a palace and a column for the governor of Odesa and many other public buildings. Many beautiful and impressive buildings are located on the Seaside Boulevard.

Odesa boasts many monuments, including exposed fragments of the remains of a Greek settlement from VI-V in B.C.E., the Vorontsov palace, Belina-Brzozowski palace, the seat of the City Council, monuments to Prince Richelieu and Pushkin, gathered around the UNESCO-listed Seaside Boulevard. Museum lovers will certainly not be disappointed in Odessa's offer: around 20 institutions of this type operate here, including Fleet Museum, Archaeological Museum, Museum of East and West Art.

The city offers a wide range of cultural events, including the Humorina Festival of humor and satire attracting hundreds of tourists every year and City Days. In Odessa there are many parks and public gardens, among which there are Preobrazhensky, Gorky and Victory parks. The city also has a university botanical garden, which recently celebrated its 200th anniversary.

Odessa is also famous for the Soviet violin school, founded by Piotr Stoljarski. Musicians such as Nathan Milstein, David Oistrakh, Igor Oistrakh, Boris Goldstein, Zakhar Bron, and Sviatoslav Richter created his works here (he was only a student at the Odessa school), Benno Moiseiwitsch, Vladimir de Pachmann, Shura Cherkassky, Emil Gilels, Maria Grinberg, Simon Barere, Leo Podolsky and Jakow Zak.

The International Film Festival in Odessa is held annually from 2010 to the present day.

Odesa is the seat of several universities (17), the oldest of them was founded in 1865. The most famous and most prestigious university is Odesa II Mechnikov National University. In addition to the National University, the city is the seat of, among others: the National University of Economics, the Odessa Law Academy, the National Telecommunications Academy and the Odessa Maritime University. The last of these institutions is a highly specialized and prestigious university training commercial seafarers, annually about 1,000 newly qualified officers.

In addition to all the universities and state-owned academies mentioned above, Odessa is also home to a large number of private educational institutes that offer high-quality courses in various fields. These universities usually charge much higher fees than state educational institutions.

They following universities are located here, among others: Medical Academy, Academy of Construction and Architecture, Food Academy, Music Academy, Technical University, National Refrigeration Academy. In Odessa, there is also the oldest research institute of Ukraine.

From 31 August to 3 September 2019, the annual feast of our partner city of Odessa was held (the 225th birthday of the City).

The programme included, among others, the opening ceremony of the City for residents and tourists and a gala at which representatives of business and culture distinguished for the City of Odessa were awarded. In addition, representatives of Odessa's partner cities were officially welcomed, including Lodz, Regensburg (Germany), Haifa (Israel), Ningbo (People's Republic of China), Lefkada (Greece). The Odessa City Day celebrations were crowned with an open-air concert of Ukrainian artists.

A delegation from Odesa is paying a visit to ÅódÅº. Guests from Ukraine familiarized themselves with the Polish emergency medical system and shared their own experience in the functioning of healthcare in Ukraine. Creation of a joint Polish-Ukrainian training center is also planned.

The delegation from Ukraine for 5 days in ÅódÅº got to know, among others, the functioning of the 112 emergency number, the organization of the State Medical Rescue System, visited, among others Provincial Medical Rescue Station, Ambulance Air Base and MikoÅaj Kopernik Regional Hospital.

"On 2nd May last year, Odesa underwent a very serious medical emergency test. 43 people died in war clashes and almost 300 people were injured. The city faced a huge challenge and we want to share it with ÅódÅº as well. We need support in gaining experience in crisis management methods and city security in similar situations that took place in Odesa. This is the aim pf our visit to ÅódÅº, we want to learn from the partner city how to act" emphasized Elena Tieriajewa from the Department of Health Protection of the Odesa Regional State Administration.

The Deputy Mayor of ÅódÅº Krzysztof PiÄ tkowski is convinced that the experience, even gained in such crisis situations, must be drawn.

The official delegation of ÅódÅº together with representatives of Falck Medycyna Sp z o.o. took part in the Festival of the City of Odessa at the invitation of Mayor Gennadiy Trukhanov. The programme of the stay included many meetings in the City Hall as well as in the Odessa Voivodship Office in the field of building local government structures, their functioning and financing, as well as the principles of the Health Service in Poland. The visit was a continuation of the talks undertaken in June this year, during the stay of the delegation of representatives of the Odesa Health Department in ÅódÅº. The inhabitants of Odesa want to learn not only how to cooperate in emergency medical services, but also broadly understood civil protection. Tragic events of 2nd May 2014, when two opposing political groups clashed in the city center, resulting in 43 deaths. These experiences forced the City and Voivodship Authorities to analyze and take action in the field of health care reform. Because at the time of crisis it turned out that the city was completely unprepared for such events. There was no coordination of rescue and medical services, hospitals were overcrowded, chaos reigned, there was no possibility of segregating the wounded, and these were victims with post-burn and gunshot wounds. Ukraine is currently on the threshold of many state reforms. This is a very important time in the history of Ukraine, therefore ÅódÅº as a partner city supports Odesa and shares its knowledge and experience.

During 3-day meeting, our city hosted 400 participants from Ukraine, EU, Russia, neighboring countries and the USA, including representatives of governments, politics, business, local governments, international organizations and analytical centers. Meetings with key persons of the European Commission and European Parliament, ministers, members of parliaments, representatives of international organizations, major companies and experts were planned.

The debates of the Europe-Ukraine 2015 Forum focused on key issues of modernization and development of Ukraine's economic potential as well as the use of its own natural resources and the possibilities of regional centers, in cooperation with partners from Poland and European Union member states. The subject of reports, panel discussions and presentations of the Forum were adaptation processes during the association of Ukraine with the European Union, energy security and economic reforms. The conditions of building a modern territorial self-government and shaping the responsibility of the society for the affairs of the state were considered. Ukraine's security issues in the structure of European and global relations were also raised.

During the ceremonial opening of the conference at the Poznanski Palace, the Mayor of ÅódÅº Hanna Zdanowska pointed out that ÅódÅº is an example of a city where people of different cultures collaborated intensively to create the industrial center of Poland.

Witold StÄpieÅ, the Marshal of the Åódzkie Voivodship, in his welcoming speech stressed that cooperation between Lodz and Ukrainian cities has been going on continuously since the beginning of the 1990s. This cooperation is both economic and at the local government level, which is why ÅódÅº is the perfect place to organize such conferences.

Zygmunt Berdychowski, Chairman of the Program Council of the Economic Forum, in turn, emphasized that the history of Ukraine of the last 20 years is similar to the history of Europe: full of ups, searching for development paths, and there are also difficult moments. In his opinion, one of the main goals of the conference is to look for ways to prevent further escalation of the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

The conference was organized by the Institute for Eastern Studies Foundation and the City of ÅódÅº and the Åódzkie Voivodeship.

The audience in Odesa enthusiastically and emotionally received the spectacle "Fiddler on the Roof" prepared by the Musical Theater in ÅódÅº.
